Al Pacino in â€œDog Day Afternoonâ€
In the suspenseful 1975 drama â€œDog Day Afternoon,â€ Al Pacino plays theÂ real-life Sonny Wortzik, a man who tries to rob a bank and ends upÂ holding people hostage so that he can get money for his boyfriendâ€™sÂ sex-change operation. Pacino received an Oscar nod for his role in theÂ movie.


Al Pacino and Other Stars of â€œAngels in Americaâ€Â  Â 
Years after â€œDog Day Afternoon,â€ Al Pacino won an Emmy and a GoldenÂ  Globe for his portrayal of closeted gay attorney Roy Cohn in the 2003Â miniseries â€œAngels in America,â€ which was based on the award-winningÂ play. Other cast members who play gay men in the film include PatrickÂ Wilson, Jeffrey Wright, Ben Shenkman and Justin Kirk.


Matt Damon in â€œThe Talented Mr. Ripleyâ€
In the 1999 drama â€œThe Talented Mr. Ripley,â€ Matt Damon is Tom Ripley, aÂ con artist whose sexual obsession with a rich playboy named â€œDickeyâ€Â Â (Jude Law) leadsÂ to tragic results (Ripley murders â€œDickeyâ€Â and his homosexual lover). By the way, Lawâ€™s big-screen debut (in 1997â€™sÂ â€œWildeâ€) was as a gay character: In the movie, Law plays Lord AlfredÂ Â â€œBosieâ€ Douglas, the lover of famous writer Oscar Wilde (Stephen Fry).



Heath LedgerÂ and Jake Gyllenhaal in â€œBrokeback Mountainâ€
Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal each got Oscar nominations for theirÂ unforgettable roles in 2005â€™s â€œBrokeback Mountainâ€ as closeted gayÂ cowboys Ennis Del Mar and Jack Twist, who fall in love. This wasnâ€™tÂ Ledgerâ€™s first role as a gay man: Ledger also played a gay teen in theÂ Australian drama series â€œSweat.â€





Charlize Theron and Christina Ricci in â€œMonsterâ€
Charlize Theron (pictured at right) won an Academy Award for bestÂ actress for her chilling portrayal of real-life serial killer AileenÂ Wuornos in 2003â€™s â€œMonster.â€ Christina Ricci (pictured at left) playsÂ Aileenâ€™s lesbian lover, Selby Wall, in the movie.





Sean Penn, James Franco, Emile Hirsch and Diego Luna inÂ Â â€œMilkâ€
Speaking of Academy Awards, Sean Penn is getting serious Oscar buzz forÂ his role as Harvey Milk in the 2008 docudrama â€œMilk.â€ In the movie, PennÂ plays the assassinated San Francisco city supervisor, who was the firstÂ openly gay politician in the United States. The majority of theÂ characters in â€œMilkâ€ are openly gay, including those portrayed by JamesÂ Franco (top right), Emile Hirsch (bottom left) and Diego Luna, as menÂ who have important influences on Milkâ€™s life.



Will Smith in â€œSix Degrees of Separationâ€
Will Smith plays a con artist (who happens to be gay) impersonatingÂ Sidney Poitierâ€™s son in the 1993 drama â€œSix Degrees of Separation.â€ InÂ the movie, Smithâ€™s character endears himself to a wealthy marriedÂ couple, and he seduces their son.



Michelle Pfeiffer andÂ Whoopi Goldberg in â€œThe Deep End Of The Oceanâ€
Whoopi Goldberg plays a homosexual detective, searching for a missingÂ kidnapped child, Ben, who miraculously reappears across the countryÂ 9-years later in Chicago under the name Sam.

Glenn Close in â€œServing in Silence: The Margarethe Cammermeyer Storyâ€
Glenn Close won an Emmy for her starring role in the 1995 TV movieÂ  â€œServing in Silence: The Margarethe Cammermeyer Story.â€ In the biopic,Â she plays the decorated Colonel Margarethe Cammermeyer, who fights herÂ dismissal from the Army when she comes out as a lesbian.


Tom Hanks and Antonio Banderas in â€œPhiladelphiaâ€

Antonio Banderas plays Andrewâ€™s lover in the movie. In hisÂ Oscar acceptance speech, Hanks famously thanked one of his formerÂ teachers, who happens to be gay.

Howard then goes on a journey to accept hisÂ sexuality, with the help of an openly gay reporter (Tom Selleck), whoâ€™sÂ assigned to do a story about the outed teacher.




Hilary Swank in â€œBoys Donâ€™t Cryâ€
Hilary Swank got her first Oscar for playing hate-crime victim BrandonÂ Teena in 1999â€™s â€œBoys Donâ€™t Cry,â€ the real-life story about a youngÂ woman living as a man. Brandon becomes romantically involved withÂ another young woman (played by ChloÃ« Sevigny, but the transgenderâ€™s lifeÂ comes to a tragic end.

Meryl Streep, Allison Janney, Ed Harris and Jeff DanielsÂ in â€œThe Hoursâ€
Speaking of Meryl Streep, she and Allison Janney (pictured at right)Â play longtime lesbian lovers in the 2002 drama â€œThe Hours.â€ Ed HarrisÂ and Jeff Daniels portray a former couple in the movie, and Harris wasÂ nominated for an Academy Award for his role in â€œThe Hours.â€

Semitism is actually a "racist" concept and therefore anti-semitism is "anti-racist"... funny how that works.
A quick search in encyclopedias reveals that the idea of a 'Semitic people' is a racial term popular in the 19th and early 20th centuries, important in establishing the history of these ancient ethnic groups (Source: Wikipedia).
The origin of the term "Semitism" in fact comes from the biblical "SHEM" (Hebrew) the name designates one of the three sons of Noah in the Book of Genesis. The term (originating in 1770 by members of the GÃ¶ttingen School) then makes reference to a culture and race of a "chosen people" that have a closer connection to God than any others. One can suggest that these efforts to elevate (or distinguish) one's own "people" in this way smack of arrogance, elitism, prejudice against other people and gave rise to antisemitism.
Antisemitism doesn't then refer to anti-Judaism (in a religious context), or anti-zionism (which would be Israel people or its defenders)... only a would-be racial supremacist ideal of Jewishness. So when you hear "antisemitism" from pundits just ask them what doctrine they actually defend.

Harry Ostrer, Jewish Professor of Genetics even demonstrates that "Shem" refers to a Jewish race found in DNA for more info on that you can check the following links:

- "Legacy: A Genetic History of the Jewish People":
http://forward.com/culture/155742/jews-are-a-race-genes-reveal/

So the simple definition of "anti-semitism" would be "anti-racism" if semitism defends racial dogma, ideals or doctrines - in any way or form.
And it's clear some today equate the SHEM gene with "semitism" as a distinct jewish ethnic identity and race even down to DNA levels...
So the definition is still being re-written.

In 1970 gay activists protested against the APA convention in San Francisco. These scenes were repeated in 1971, and as people came out of the â€œclosetâ€ and felt empowered politically and socially, the APA directorate became increasingly uncomfortable with their stance. Â In 1973 the APAâ€™s nomenclature task force recommended that homosexuality be declared normal. Â The trustees were not prepared to go that far, but they did vote to remove homosexuality from the list of mental illnesses by a vote of 13 to 0, with 2 abstentions. Â This decision was confirmed by a vote of the APA membership, and homosexuality was no longer listed in the seventh edition of DSM-II, which was issued in 1974.Â 

Whatâ€™s noteworthy about this is that the removal of homosexuality from the list of mental illnesses was not triggered by some scientific breakthrough. Â There was no new fact or set of facts that stimulated this major change. Â Rather, it was the simple reality that gay people started to kick up a fuss. Â They gained a voice and began to make themselves heard. Â And the APA reacted with truly astonishing speed. Â And with good reason. They realized intuitively that a protracted battle would have drawn increasing attention to the spurious nature of their entire taxonomy. Â So they quickly â€œcut looseâ€ the gay community and forestalled any radical scrutiny of the DSM system generally.

Copperfield is a master; great use of props, music, pyro and showmanship. This one isn't hard to figure out though. The helmet is the key. Notice that once he puts it on, he never removes it or lifts the visor. Right before the lift apparatus is revealed, there is a brief moment where he disappears behind the curtain. A switch takes place. Someone with the same helmet, jacket and build as Copperfield is the one elevated, while David is running through the bowels of the arena to the reveal point. When the pyro goes off, something obscures cycle 1 and Not David from view, while David and bike 2 are revealed elsewhere.

Okay half of you didn't watch the video and the other half (including the show hosts) don't know the difference between being arrested and being detained. If police show up to a scene of an assault, whether it was the case of a hero or not, they have to do their jobs. Police aren't mind readers and they're not the wizard of oz. They show up on scene, someone is bleeding, someone else is screaming about a rape, and someone else is screaming about self defense. The police department's job is to take control of the situation and proceed with further action if necessary. What the man did was fantastic, I hope the pedo goes to jail. But I was honestly surprised by the fact that the police didn't just immediately handcuff both of them. Detainment of both parties happens every time there is any kind of assault or battery, whether the police witness it or not. Both parties were detained, not arrested, and questioned. From that point, the defender was released, never arrested, and the pedo was likely arrested for sexual assault. Before you go screaming that the police didn't do things correctly, think about what it's like to show up to the scene of an assault, not knowing what has happened, who's the bad guy, who's got a Glock in their waste-band, who's going to run from you, who's got warrants, who's a violent criminal. Use your brains a little before you jump on the band wagon America.

By the way.... this video literally has NOTHING to do with race. Stop trying to make everything about race. YOU'RE THE PROBLEM. These officers would have done the exact same thing whether the person was black white or purple.

While that is true i think many here are missing the point of objection. You will know a tree by its fruit. Drawing close to God produces righteousness by faith that is in accord with the Spirit of law, not self righteousness that seeks to impose the letter of the law. Jesus calls us to be his ambassadors as if God were making his appeal through us to be reconciled. Jesus went to the cross and made attonement for all sin. Now anyone can humble themselves and believe in him. This requires that a person hear the word of faith we are proclaiming, experience godly sorrow that produces repentance of dead works that leads to salvation through faith in Christ. Having done so honestly they areÂ  born from above and enter into Christ. They start as carnal infants in Christ and need discipleship. They are taught how to obey the commands of Christ by word and example, summed up by 1 John 3 (23 And this is His commandment: that we should believe in the name of His Son, Jesus Christ, and we should love one another just as He commanded us.Â 24Whoever keeps His commandments remains in God, and God in him. And by this we know that He remains in us: by the Spirit He has given us.) Though we see most of them given in matt 5 & 6. (We know this because it was the way of life for those who followed The Way for the first 300 years before Augustine introduced his semi-gnostic drivel right before his death.) Most the commands of Christ have to do with loving others, including unbelievers, in deed and Truth. Yes Jesus brought the law to the proud and self righteous, but his grace on others is clearly seen. The woman caught in audultry. Where are your accusers? Neither do i condemn you, go and sin no more. He ate with them and loved them while being righteous himself, not self righteous. He was salt and light amidst the darkness and His presence drew people in. Everything we saw him do was in the Spirit of love, because God is love, light, and Spirit. 

His righteous indignation was reserved for the religious legalists, who not only wouldn't enter in but actively prevented those who wanted to from doing so, and sought only to place legal burdens on people which they weren't willing to follow completely themselves. They were religious hypocrites that could expound upon the law perfectly and yet inside they were full of dead man's bones. They didn't understand the point of the law was to increase transgression and drive us to our saviour. Summed up perfectly in jesus' soteriological example of godly sorrow and repentance in Luke 18; two men stood in tree temple praying. The first a proud self-righteous Pharisee. He said, "God, I thank You that I am not like the other menâ€”swindlers, evildoers, adulterersâ€”or even like this tax collector.Â I fast twice a week and pay tithes of all that I receive.â€™"(might at homosexual to that list?ğŸ˜‰) The second man was that tax collector. A man who betrayed his own people to Rome for coin, considered the lowest of the low by the people. Jesus said this man stood at a distance and wouldn't even lift his head to heaven. He beat his and cried saying, "God, have mercy on me, a sinner!" Jesus concluded by saying the tax collector rather then the Pharisee went home justified in his sight. because of his humility and faith. He had repentance from dead works and judged himself rightly. He realised he was undone and could only humble himself and ask for mercy, which he received. The other man who was moral and kept the letter of the law was lost in his sinful self righteous pride. 

We are called to follow Jesus. That means being a light in a dark world. Making known the sinfulness of man and yet the Grace of God that abounds despite it. That whosoever is willing to humble themselves in faith will receive mercy. Standing at a pulpit and railing against "gays" and "queers" and anyone else thatc doesn't fit in your small self righteous box, is the opposite of being Christ like. Jesus was full of grace and Truth, not weak. He had compassion and empathy for the hurting and lost, while not shying away from the hard Truths. He was able to build relationships with people and caused them to see the Truth. Some loved the Truth so as to be saved and some surpressed the Truth in unrighteousness. But he didn't stop loving them. He even weeped over the city, longing to gather them all to himself yet most were unwilling. They had been hardened and cut off in their rebellion, inorder to bring about the crusifiction. As Paul explains, had they known the hour of their visitation they v would not have crucified the Lord of glory. But that since they had grown dull to the things of God and shut their eyes and ears he sent them a Spirit of stupor that they might not see, hear, turn and be healed. So that the gentiles could be grafted in to Spiritual isreal. Then Paul explains that those who had stumbled had not stumbled beyond recovery. That he held out hope that his ministry to the gentiles would provoke their will to jealousy and if they left their unbelief they would be grafted back in. When Jesus ascended he sent the Holy Spirit into the world to convict the whole world of sin, righteousness, and judgment. Of sin because they don't believe in jesus, of righteousness because he was leaving to the Father and the world would no longer see him, of judgement because the god of this world had been judged. The lost are condemned already but not because they are gay, drunks, murders, fornicators, or wear tight pants...but because they have not believed in God's only son. 

Our commission is to follow Jesus and preach the gospel of God's love and provision for all wicked people. That it's not that we first loved him but that he first loved us in deed and Truth, providing salvation for everyone. So that anyone can humble themselves and repent of dead works and receive the adoption as sons through faith in Christ. He has made the way, set the conditions, and calls everyone, through us, to be reconciled back to God through faith. The righteousness that comes by works of the law are as filthy rags and commend us nut in his sight. This righteousness is out of man's reach as no one can keep the whole law from birth to death as Christ did. The righteousness that comes by faith however is near you and in your mouth. That is the faith that we proclaim. That if you believe in your heart that Jesus rose from the dead and confess with your mouth That Jesus is lord, you WILL be saved. For with the heart one believes and is justified, with the mouth one confesses and is saved. 

Our calling is to be a peculiar people set apart, zealous for good works, living sensible godly lives in this present age. It's the Grace of God that teaches us this when we experience it. As a good loving Father, he disciplines and guides us by the Spirit of Truth after we come to him

Calling something marriage does not make it marriage. Marriage in the United States has always been a covenant between a man and a woman. Supporters of same-sex marriage are faced with the idea that the main non-religious purpose of marriage is to legally recognize two peopleâ€™s commitment to one another and afford those rights that come with marriage, and more importantly the idea of conceiving and raising children. Since same-sex couples cannot conceive children that notion must be erased. They must first disentangle the religious aspect (not discussed here) and then remove from marriage the notion of childbearing; and turn marriage into a principle that government must recognize the unity of two people defined by any means as loving one another. But the world is more diverse than just straight people and homosexuals; there are polygamists and incestuous relations. Under the same principle allowing same-sex marriage it would be hypocritical, if not also unlawful, to not allow them the same marriage. Although not all husbands and wives choose to have children, or are capable of doing so, this does not alter by one iota societyâ€™s compelling interest in holding out as normative, and particularly desirable, the only type of sexual relationship that is capable of doing what is required for the perpetuation of society. Let homosexuals seek their civil union with the same legal rights as a marriage; just do not call it a marriage.
